Update v1.1: Added an optional smaller handle to speed up print times and an orientation indicator so you know which way you're stamping!
I was recently asked by my local library to design a one inch wax seal for their summer reading program. I designed the stamp in Sketchup before realizing that this would be a great candidate for Customizer!
Big thanks to Benjamin for his awesome stencil creator.
Change Log:
Update v1.1: Added an optional smaller handle to speed up print times and an orientation indicator so you know which way you're stamping!

• Upload a photo to Benjamin's Stencil-o-Matic found here: http://chaaawa.com/stencil_factory/
  • Paste the resulting code into STAMPY's input field in Customizer
  • Switch to "Print Quality" and export your STL
  • Print and start sealing things with your awesome Customized wax seal stamp!

Dont forget the Pixel Sun this Christmas :)

Was looking for a way to better control colored sugar application to cookies. came up with a small canister with a small spout to provide better control over it's application.
With a little practice you should be able to draw a fairly narrow line of sugar on your cookies or cake.
It's small size was intended to allow better control and allow small hands to use it too.
Tips: Rotate the canister slightly left or right to obtain a narrower line, tap lightly on the canister with your finger to get the sugar flowing.

Material: HIPS or other food safe filament.
infill 30%
raft & supports OFF
Container is designed to have friction fit lid & top spout.
You may need to lightly sand the lid & canister to obtain a snug but removable fit. The pin to hold the lid/spout on will likely need to have the end of it sanded to get it started in the hole. Be careful not to sand more than the very end of the pin or it may not fit tightly enough to hold the spout top on. Recommend 220 grit for the sanding.

DESCRIPTION:
A five or seven character cryptex that can be used as a small safe / money box and is ideal for storing small valuable items that need the kind of security that only comes form a pocket sized safe made of plastic.
Enjoy!


KEY FEATURES:
• 100,000 or 10,000,000 possible combinations for the 5 ring and 7 ring versions respectively. • Each ring can be set to a custom number and can be changed at any time, by anyone possessing the combination to unlock the cryptex + Locking Tool. • If you wish, you can design your own custom combination rings using this OpenSCAD file:
Outer Ring Customizer (OpenScad). • Sturdy construction. Unlike many other designs, this one features a locking component that holds the cryptex together even when open, thus stopping it from fall apart while in this state. • Easy print. Designed specifically for the 3D printing there is very little by way of overhangs and thus no support structures are needed. Theoretically the parts should require no cleaning and can be assembled strait off the build plate. All .STL file have already been rotated for best print results.


IMPORTANT NOTES:
1) Although there are no support structures to clean up i have fount, on account of the components being a naturally snug fitting, even small imperfections in the print can cause parts to become tight or catch. So keep the craft knife or sandpaper on hand just in case :) 2) I have created a couple of remixes of this design that you might also like to check out:
Combination Safe 00 _ for the Visually Impaired (Despite the name, not all the features of this design were created exclusively for the blind users)
Combination Safe 00 - Dual Material Rings


MODIFICATION UPDATES:
Date:10.05.15
Component: Lid_v1
Modification: The lid is now slightly shorter which should solve the stiffness of the bottom ring.

Date: 10.05.15
Component: Bottom_lock_v1
Modification: Added a chamfer to outer bottom edge to prevent over tight tolerances from flare out.

Date: 15.11.15
Component: Lid_v2
Modification: Have made tiny reduction to diameter of outer edge, so it should fit into the outer_ring more easily now.

Date: 16.12.15
Component: Bottom_Lock_v2
Modification: Moved the lip so the it releases the locking tool when turned clockwise too the locked position and vice versa.

Date: 16.12.15
Component: Bottom_v3
Modification: fractionally wider inner diameter to provent tapering of Inner_tube which caused the Lid to be stick.

Date: 16.12.15
Component: Locking_tool_v2
Modification: Mostly just a cosmetic change

Date: 13.03.16
Component: Inner_Shaft_7R_v0
Modification: A taller version of the original design, allowing it to accommodate two additional rings.

Date: 13.03.16
Component: Lid_7R_v0
Modification: A taller version of the original design, allowing it to accommodate two additional rings.

Date: 13.03.16
Component: Locking_tool_7R_v0
Modification: A taller version of the original design so it can be used with the 7 ring version of the cryptex.

Date: 28.03.16
Component: Lid_R5_Holey_v0
Modification: Alternative lid design. Added holes to the lid so its easier to see inside.

comments.text: Just rub the touching faces with a little bar soap before assembly.  I find this works amazingly well for PLA.  Might also work for other plastics.
comments.author: itsdavidyang

comments.text: I'm having trouble fitting the inner ring onto the inner shaft. The shaft pieces just come together and I can't get it all the way down. I am also having trouble with the rings because sometimes it prints unevenly on the bottom part. The top is fine, but the bottom will curl off the build plate. I'm printing with abs and a brim. any suggestions?
comments.author: enderjack

comments.text: For the inner ring fit, did you check to see if you have any burrs or ridges on the ID of the ring? If your printer isn't dialed in just right, sometimes you'll get a little burr around the bottom and/or top edge. If you've got the burrs, a little sanding or scraping with a sharp knife should get rid of them (I tend to scrape rather than whittle). I had to polish the ID of some of my inner rings to improve the fit - especially on the 5th ring, where it meets the base of the inner shaft (I also polished that inner shaft a bit right where it met the base)
comments.author: enderjack

comments.text: When I printed the 5-ring version in actual size, things were a bit tight, but a bit of sanding and filing here and there got things to fit. When I printed the 7-ring scaled up to 1.5X things were a little looser. I still had to tweak the bottom and the bottom lock a bit to get them to go together, and the inner and outer ring fit was a bit loose (the rings would have worked, but I snugged things up a bit by just bumping up my flow rate 1.5% - probably not the best way to fix it, but it worked.)  The 7 ring 1.5X all went together fairly well. The rings spin much easier than on the actual size print I made, but still very usable.

comments.text:
I didn't quite follow all of what you were saying but ill try to offer what support i can.
in my own experience tightness between the lid and inner_shaft is normally the result of visible imperfections on the print suface and should be possible to fix with a bit of sanding. If your not already doing so, pring at a nice leisurely speed say 30mm/s should reduce these imperfections.
If your using different filaments for the lid and inner_shaft its also possible they r contracting too differant amounts thus causing tighness.
I'll check the sauce files but the outer diameter of both lids should be the same. If u do find u have to rescale only do so on the X&Y axis to avoid "screw up how the inner rings lock into the teeth"
let me know how u get on. the feedback is helpful for when other people have problems.

comments.text:
i've always understood visually stuff much better, so i'm not convinced a written explanation is going to help if u don't already get it, but here gos.
If you imagine the the safe in cross section cut from top to botton though the center. The profile of one of the teeth, on the lid, is the inverse of the profile of the inside of the inner ring. (like a screw head is the inverse of a screw bit) Therefor if the inner ring is correctly aligned with the teeth the two profiles have no points of overlap and thus can rotate freely past one anther because the inside profile remains constant even while in rotation. The ring cant move up or down of course, because this would mean the profiles would be overlapping i.e. occupy the same space, except where the slots are cut to allow the thing to open.
u know, u could have just printed it :)

comments.text: So I've been thinking about the design, and I've concluded that the Locking Tool slot in the Bottom Lock is the wrong way around. When you've locked the Bottom Lock in place, you then have to rotate the Locking Tool counterclockwise to undock it from the lock, but that same movement also unlocks the Bottom Lock part again. And the same happens when unlocking the Bottom Lock: you twist it counterclockwise, which means you will undock the Bottom Lock from the Locking Tool as well. title: Balanced Strap lugs for Sputnik Stereo camera

description.text: Update to my original design These are well-balanced strap lugs for a Sputnik Russian stereo camera. I have designed them to work in both plastic, and stainless steel. A printable part (Works in plastic, but I decided to have mine made in stainless steel) that lets you attach a strap to the Russian Sputnik Camera. For some odd reason the designers of the Russian Sputnik Stereo Camera felt that no one would want to use this big bulky thing with a camera strap. Well, I did. So I went ahead and printed out these simple strap lugs. They replace the black metal winding knob parts which adds a strap lug to the camera. I have tried and tested this part in both plastic, and stainless steel, and while I do trust the plastic, I much prefer the stainless (Which is shown above)

-Print it out (I printed mine in both plastic and stainless, and they both work)
-Cut and sand the parts down.
-Replace the original knob-mounts.
-Attach your favorite strap
-Run around!

title: TRAP! Improved Springs Stronger and No Support

description.text:
I was having problems with my springs warping when I printed them because of the support I had to use.  So I just made the spring part taller.  This makes it so the springs can print without support and are even stronger than the originals.  
I added two more stl files a single spring and a single spring with hold down disks to prevent lifting during printing.
These should print just fine without support.  Use support if you think you need it.

author: MacGyver

title: E3D V6 Hot end Mount for Ormerod

description.text:
Mount for ED3's V6 all metal hot end for RepRapPro's Ormerod 3d printer. It is a direct replacement for the standard Ormerod hot end. No Z axis height is lost switching to this mount.   
The assembled hot end with a 11x40mm fan installed measures 42x40mm and weighs 83g. The Stock Ormerod Hot end with it's 20x40 fan Measures 52x58mm and is 96g. A 35% infill was used for both hot end's printed parts. The V6 assembly is both smaller and lighter then the standard Ormerod hot end.   
I have had no issues in testing. Printing at 180c for PLA there was no visible effect on any of the mount parts. I have not printed any ABS, however I kept it at 250c for 1 hour and there was no visible change on the PLA mount, however I still suggest printing the mount in ABS if you will be using higher temps.

1x E3D V6 hot end
1x 10x40mm fan
2(4) M3x40 cap head screws(2 recycled from stock hot end)
2(4) M3 Nuts
2 M3x12 Countersunk screws(recycled from stock nozzle mount) E3D-v6 All Metal HotEnd
Instructions for assembling and commissioning the E3D V6 can be found here http://e3d-online.com/E3D-v6-Assembly. I highly recommend completing this before installing the V6 on the printer. Use the follwing line in your config.g file to configure the Duet to use the Semitec 104GT2 thermistor that comes with the V6 kit. M305 P1 T100000 R1000 B4267
Users with the updated Duet with 4k7 thermistor series resistor will need to use a R value of 4700
The M305 command is only supported in Firmware Version 0.78c or higher Duet Firmware
Ensure you are running version 0.78c of the RepRap Firmware or newer. The latest version is available at https://github.com/reprappro/RepRapFirmware . There are various forks available. I personally use DC42's Fork. Mount
First print the Nozzle mount and Fan duct. Remove the old hot end and nozzle mount while retaining the M3x40 screws and M3x12 counter sunk screws you will need these for the new assembly. Take the new Nozzle mount and place 4 M3 nuts into the captive slots on the back. Then using the M3x12 screws, mount it to the X carriage. Take the E3D V6 hot end and and place it into the fan duct, ensure you have your wires on the desired side of the assembly(Tie holes are on both sides of the nozzle mount). place the fan on the flat side of the fan duct and insert the 3Mx40 screws, align it with the nozzle mount and push them through to engage the M3 nuts. Tightening the screws will secure the parts around the hot end.

author: Kodt

description.text:
Needed a cabinet to keep my Arduino parts in. Everything I found online was too small. This project will push your printer to the limit (at least mine). The cabinet is 5 5/8' deep, 5 1/2" tall, and 8 5/8" wide. (Not including the handles.)  
Additionally, the drawers are .1" thick on all sides so they could hold some weight. This used a lot more PLA than I thought. I might redo the drawer thickness sometime down the line.  
NOTE: By request, added the 123dx files (source files) so this thing can be edited to your preferences.

My printer has a published print volume of 6" by 6" by 9". Because of this, I did not do any rafting, just printed directly on the plate. Print times were 14 hrs for the cabinet and 7-8 hrs for each drawer. I printed the cabinet on it's back.  
The DrawerX.stl refer to the number of bins in each drawer.   
NOTE: The cabinet has a top and bottom. I have placed small bumps in the front corners of each level to stop the drawer from being pulled all the way-out accidentally. If the drawers won't go in, flip it over.

description.text: This is a surprisingly difficult puzzle for a lot of people, both to assemble and disassemble (provided you have a good friction fit between the parts).  I was inspired by a similar wooden puzzle that was given to me, but that one had different types of pieces with a key block that made assembly quite easy.  I realized no key was necessary, so I made this version and changed the shape slightly.

Just print six identical pieces and assemble them into a sphere as shown. I included a parametric openSCAD file so you can choose your size and change the shape if you desire. There is also an important parameter to tweak: tolerance. I needed half a millimeter to account for the inaccuracies of my TOM and allow the parts to assemble. You might have to tweak this to make sure the parts can go together, but don't spontaneously fall apart. UPDATE:
I changed the scad file (and corresponding stl) to do the tolerances in a more symmetric way such that the final shape is more nearly spherical. Still prints well on a stock TOM with the same tolerance value as before.

title: Ball Joint Fan mount for Printrbot Simple

description.text: Taken from ei8htohms' Articulated Ball Joint Fan Mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139984, revised to replace the cooling fan on the Printrbot Simple 1401. I had to cut part of the wood to make room for the clips that hold my hotbed together. The fan wasn't staying on the end of ei8htohms model I printed so I've replaced that cup joint with the bigger one. I've also included a 'middle piece' of 2x ball joint to extend the arm.

Recommend printing the FanMount upright, as is, with support material. Ball joints print best upright I found, which is why the MidPiece is split in half.   
Use M3 bolts to fasten the PrintrbotMount to the top two holes originally used for your cooling fan. snap the ball joints in the cup joints on the Arms, then use a bolt and nut to tighten the arm. Sandwich the cooling fan between the hood and the FanMount.

title: Pocket-Tactics: Core Rules (Third Edition)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is the third (and now outdated) core rules for our modular, tile-based strategy boardgame, Pocket-Tactics. For the new (and much improved) Fourth Edition sets and pieces, check out this collection. We'll be updating the new edition to include rules for all of the Third Edition units, so if you have printed them (or want to), check in for updates and eventually all of those pieces' rules will be available. Also, in case you prefer this third edition stuff, we'll keep it around here and in this collection. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy! [http://youtu.be/i1YF8dQfzWs]()

comments.text: Another rules question.  The rules do not specifically state that when deploying you can hop an allied unit if all tiles adjacent to your base are occupied.  Does this mean that you cannot deploy if there is no open space next to your base after the first turn? Or does this mean that you can borrow from the movement rule to hop one space adjacent to the unit next to the base? We have been playing the latter so far but want to get it right.
comments.author: MonkeyRobot22

comments.text: Actually, the first. You can't deploy if the tiles around your base are occupied (unless you have a power that let's you deploy elsewhere, like the Darkwood Stalker or something). Deployment isn't technically movement. As such, you don't suffer hazard effects when you deploy into a Water or Cave tile or the like, but moving into them does.
comments.author: MonkeyRobot22

comments.text: So a bane plauge (Mage Spell) on a Voolan army wipes the army?
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Nah, like it says in the rules, Technical DEF and Arcane DEF are interchangeable. But, it could potentially be devastating (DV4 is generally 50/50 with those guys).
comments.author: The_Necrocomicon

comments.text: Thanks I was a little confused because the rules specify that they are interchangeable for assults, but Mage spells have you resist with skill tests, so it's good to know it covers there too, on a similar note does an Arcanist's Warding Spells Work on something like the Unenlightened Tengu's Spiteful Swoop?
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Right, wouldn't work against that, because that power bypasses Assault categorization. Similarly, the Heavy's ability (in the Freespace Privateers) wouldn't be affected by the Arcanist's ability. In the Mage Guild spell card rules it should read that any test required to be made to resist a spell is considered an assault roll, but in the new rules, all units have both Arcane and Tech DEF, and the distinction is less important. This edition will be pretty much defunct by the time we release the new stuff (getting a Kickstarter campaign ready now as we finish up working out production specs) but it's a good primer for what's to come.

comments.text: Yeah, absolutely! You can definitely play with more than two players, we actually do that all the time. We're working on a rules update that includes multiplayer rules, but basically, you build the map outward in all directions from one tile. All opposing players have to have their bases a least 6 tiles apart, allies ()if you're playing with teams) at least 3 apart. Knocking someone's base out in a multiplayer game doesn't end the player's involvement necessarily, they just can't bring units out of reserves any longer (unless they can do so by other means, like special abilities, etc)

We played our first game last night (also part of Area 51 :p) between the Forces of Hel and the Sons of Dvalinn.
Was a blast to play though we hit a couple of snags: In the core rules there is no mention of when a stat has a number in brackets underneath it - we took it as an invulnerable save 40k style so that even if the opponent had more successes than you (or a larger die pool), only the dice that were the same or higher than this number counted as successes. Also the wall objects in the forces of Hel mentioned granting bonuses to kickers.... and nothing else did O_O (took that to mean any units in the surrounding hexes)
We also found the tiles with directional limits (caves, paths/labyrinths etc) a little too confusing for a first play so skipped over them. It didn't help that the board had already been drawn before we noticed them :p

Its definitely no big deal to skip tunnel rules for a game, because they do make things more complicated, but once you get them, they can really add to the strategy. So glad you guys are playing! We're starting our first campaign in a few days, and we'll be blogging about it/releasing the campaign components (and some new sets) as we go.

Each side is just over 10 inches long. I haven't printed it yet, but I've included pegs for aligning the pieces.

author: guco

title: Game Controller Comfort Grips for Nintendo 3dsXL
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hands hurt after gaming on your 3dsXL?
Maybe you're old, hands too big, or the control scheme just doesn't situate ..
Well.. you can experiment with my latest gamepad-style gaming grips! This is a hybrid style between Playstation and Gamecube which I feel works quite well for the wide body and weight of the 3dsXL. Takes very little plastic.. quick to print! You' only need 4 small screws, I used M3x6.
Screen angle for 3d is perfect with no funny "ghosting" & you can just let your hands relax and hold your 3ds like a modern console controller. Most 'things' unimpeded, holes for pretty much everything else (stylus, volume fader, bumpered cartridge slot, IR, DC, accessory mounting holes, headphone port) ..it doesn't close 100%, but very nearly..more than far enough to go into sleep mode. I also threw on an earbud cord organizer to keep things tidy up front. Enjoy & Happy Holidays!

Update 12-29-2014:   
(UPDATED_3ds_right_grip_v2.3): v2.3 I've added a small hole on the right grip for the wireless on/off toggle switch.   
The old version without the hole, v2.2, will remain available.

Print the bracket on your high infill setting. Print the handles however you see fit for your printer and filament. Remove the supports with tweezers, needlenose pliers, or a hobby knife, then be sure to do a thorough clean up job to remove scraps or plastic tabs. clean up sharp stuff with light sanding or heat. Next, assemble onto the unit, by sliding the pieces together over the 3dsXL. Start with the bracket, slide on from the back of the 3ds base, then center. Place both handles in their respective positions and slide it all onto the 3dsXL + bracket
.
Compress the pieces together, ensuring the holes for the screws are all in place. (Clasp the entire unit by both controller handles, or use the rings on the backside.. just keep it tight.. then alternating sides, screw 4 M3x6 screws into each hole.

Yo Lateimew333!

comments.author: Latimew333

comments.text: I've looked at the model by Javaco and there are quite a few things that don't match up with the actual console, so I'm going to have to find the dimensions myself and make my own model. The only thing I think I might have a problem with are the chamfers, since as far as I can tell there no way to measure them accurately with a caliper, but it will probably turn out fine with some trial and error. Thank you very much for the help.
comments.author: Trezhunter

comments.text: Yea for sure. I have the exact same issues with the chafmer. I was pretty insistent on making sure the handle mating with the edge left no clearance. You can try to gauge the start and apex of the chamfer with your caliper in mm as a difference to the overall length in mm, lay your box/object on a mm grid, and try to reproduce that start point on your edge. A little guestimation + plenty of trial an error will eventually yield you a result that works. Best of luck, and I look forward to seeing your work!
comments.author: Latimew333

author: miladg

description.text:
This is a four color geometric pattern for plotting on eggs with the Eggbot.  The SVG drawing has a height of 800 pixels and has an aspect ratio appropriate for plotting on eggs.  To adjust for plotting on spheres, rescale the vertical size to a height of 1200 pixels.  Then remove rows so as to obtain the desired vertical height (e.g., 1000 pixels).
Plotting this drawing successfully requires a high degree of plotting accuracy (e.g., to prevent unwanted registration problems).  So, be sure to carefully load your egg with the correct tension. 
The included Python file is the Python code to generate the basic drawing with dimensions 1200 x 3200.  In Inkscape, I then rescaled the vertical dimension by 63.333% so as to get an aspect ratio suitable for drawing on eggs.  (66.666% might seem more apropos, but I wanted to be a tad shorter than 800 pixels and hence 63.3333%)

To aid in framing the drawing on your egg, layer "1 - test" has two short horizontal lines at y=800 and y=0.
The four remaining layers each contain a single color: 2 - yellow, 3 - orange, 4 - turquoise, and 5 - magenta.

comments.text: I just got my egg bot for Christmas and a little confused.  Maybe there is an easy way to explain layering for this old woman to understand I hope.  I would love to do this pattern.
comments.author: Sues

comments.text: Many programs for drawing computer graphics have a concept of "layers" in which you place different parts of your drawing into different conceptual layers.  They are best likened to drawing on transparent sheets of paper.  You can then stack them atop of each other and see the overall drawing. You can take a sheet (layer) and move it to the bottom of the stack so that it appears underneath/below the other sheets.  The sheets above it will occlude some or all of it.  Or, you can take a sheet at the bottom and move it above (in front of) other sheets.
comments.author: Sues

comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I'm late responding to this discussion, but wanted to say that I think Eggbot is certainly worth the price, at least from the perspective of somebody who comes from a traditional East European egg decorating background.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Thanks for the kind words.  What I enjoy most about sharing designs is seeing where other people take them -- what they do with them.  I look forward to seeing where you take them!
comments.author: Spork

comments.text: Three minutes or so to set up and frame.  Then 34 minutes (at the speeds I use) to plot the four colors, including my manually changing out the pens.   More specifically, I draw the yellow at a slower speed than the other colors so that I get good saturation.  And, there's more yellow rhombuses than for any of the other colors as well.  It ends up being 8 minutes apiece for three of the colors and about 10 minutes for the yellow.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: P.S. By much "faster", I mean in the neighborhood of 5 minutes or less.  That is, a lot of the plots I draw have far fewer pen-up-pen-down operations and consequently draw much, much faster.  This plot and the other complex geometric design I posted have lots of pen up/pen down operations and I take the pen downs fairly slowly (to be kind to my pen tips).  Hence the much longer than typical drawing times.

description.text:
If you like eating ice cream from a cone but don't like soggy cone at the end and resulting mess this could be your solution.   
Designed to regular ice cream cone size, this cone lets you add scoops as with any regular cone. It has a flat base surface approx. 20mm / 1 inch below the top rim to retain the ice cream at an easy to get to level. .   
Enjoy the ice cream as usual on this 3D printed serving dish.   
Not sure how well PLA does with dishwashers so hand washing suggested. .

Prints well on a Replicator 2 with 4 shells and 35% fill, use raft but no support as the required support is designed in. It should pull away easily from inside the rim.... then go enjoy a couple of scoops of your favourite ice cream.

Here are cat coasters 9 through 12 of the coasters based on the 17 plane groups. See Cat Coasters 01,02 - things 54736 and 56813. The four plane groups are: cmm. p4, p4m, and p4g. Three of these groups contain four fold rotation axes. p4 has only rotational symmetry, p4m and p4g contain combinations of reflection and glide lines. The four sets of files for dual extrusion are: cat_coasters_cmm.stl and cat_decorations_cmm.stl
cat_coasters_p4.stl and cat_decorations_p4.stl
cat_coasters_p4m.stl and cat_decorations_p4m.stl
cat_coasters_p4g.stl and cat_decorations_p4g.stl Cat_coasters_03 scad created the stl files and the images are in coasters_dxf_03.zip

The coasters are 110 mm in diameter and should be constructed directly on the build surface.   I used one shell and ten percent infill and the coasters printed in about two hours.
The coasters can be used as teaching aids.  Pdf files that show some of the symmetry elements are included in coasters_dxf_03.zip.  Reflection lines are shown in red and glide lines in blue.

This is a monochrome geometric drawing for plotting on eggs with the Eggbot.  The drawing is 800 x 3200 and has an aspect ratio appropriate for eggs.  To plot on spheres, rescale the image vertically to a height of 1200 pixels and then remove rows to obtain the desired height (e.g., 1000 pixels).
Drawing this plot requires a high degree of plotting precision.  You can remove a column to  prevent any poor seams from appearing and still have a pleasant plot.
FWIW, at a pen speed of around 220 steps/second, this plot takes about 30 minutes to draw.  I've had success drawing it at faster speeds (300 s/s); however, with the pens I use, I like the slower speeds for achieving better color saturation.
Layer 1, "1 - test", has two small horizontal marks to aid in framing the plot on your egg.  The actual drawing is in layer 2, "2 - blue".

comments.text: What are you using to coat the egg?
comments.author: linuxwrangler

comments.text: Valspar premium enamel semi-gloss (in a spray can).  I use four light coats: two coats with the egg standing upside down and two with it right side up in alternation.  The finish dries quite quickly as regards re-coating (10 - 15 minutes).  However, it takes about two days to really harden to where it actually seems to help harden the egg shell.
comments.author: linuxwrangler

comments.text: What size tip are you using on your pen?
comments.author: bevaninaustralia

comments.text:
The colored pens are 0.3mm Copic Multiliner SPs. I've found them to draw a finer line than Sharpie Ultra Fines which also claim 0.3mm. Also, the ink is more opaque. (Stands to reason as it is a pigment-based ink.) The black pen is a Pigma Micron 005 which claims to be 0.2mm. For really fine lines, I like the 0.1 and 0.05mm Copic Multiliner SPs. However, the black Copic Multiliner SPs have an ink that takes a while to dry on eggshells to where it won't easily smudge (
&
gt; hour). Ditto the color Copics, but not as long (
&
lt;30 minutes?).
comments.author: bevaninaustralia

comments.text: After two years of experience, would you still recommend Copic Multiliner SPs? I just purchased an egg bot recently and am experimenting with eggs and Christmas ornaments. So far, I only found the Sharpie to stick to glass properly (due to alcohol based ink). So far, I could not find any proper alcohol based fine liners which are offered in a decent color range. Another concern is, which pens are durable, UV resistant and don't bleach out. Most manufacturers don't comment on this. Copic Multiliners as well as Sharpies are not very common in Switzerland. Did you try Staedtler or Stabilo markers or can you recommend other brands?
comments.author: dnewman

comments.text: I still like Copic Multiliners which, by the way, come from Japan. They are durable, permanent, and UV resistant: their target market is the art community (e.g., illustrators). I also have a collection of sapphire tipped technical pens in which I can run whatever ink I want, as long as it flows well and doesn't have coarse particles in it which will clog the nibs.  But for glass, that's another matter.  I don't work with glass much and when I do, I either etch it or use Sharpies.  So I don't have much experience on the glass side other than I use light bulbs a lot as "erasable media": simple black sharpie for a test print, then erase with isopropyl alcohol.  My guess is that the Copic pens -- a pigmented ink -- do not work well on glass.  I've not even bothered to try.  The ink takes a bit to fully dry on chicken eggs (faster on duck eggs).  I suspect it will take several hours to dry on glass.

description.text: I got tired of soldering 50 extension arms per 7 weeks so I decided to invent a solution.  This hot glues on the right hand side and still allows you to set the mousetrap.  The extension arm hole is .129 still allowing you to drill it out a bit, its coat hanger perfect.

title: They all laughed at me...but I'LL SHOW THEM! I'LL SHOW THEM ALL!! BWAHAHAHAAA!

description.text:
Erik de Bruijn said, "I want a pink panther lady with Walt disneyÃ¢â¬â¢s brainy-head bottle opener whistle!" I have NO idea why he would want such a thing, but here it is none the less. http://makerblock.com/2011/01/best-makerbot-printed-sample-bottle-opener-leading-the-pack-with-100/#comments Derivatives of:
BrainyWalt by jmil - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:828
Thin Profile Whistle Blank by TeamTeamUSA - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5416
The Pink Panther Woman!!!! by januario - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1216
Coin-op Bottle Opener by Starno - www.thingiverse.com/thing:1842

• Download all files.
  • Use the OpenSCAD file to combine those four files into one single abomination.
  • Never, EVER print it.
    • I couldn't get OpenSCAD to render the Disney brain, but the rest of it is still pretty scary. You REALLY have to click on that picture to get the full effect.

I will post a made soon.

description.text:
It is just another extruder inspired by many beloved extruders on Thingiverse. It is for MK7 drive gear & 1.75mm filament.
  • Bearing: 696zz (OD:15mm / ID: 6mm)
  • 2 M3x10 bolts
  • 1 M3x15 bolt
  • 1 M3x25 bolt
  • 1 M3 nut
  • 2 M3 washers
  • 8mm~ spring (ID: 4mm~)
  • M5 fitting
    • Print and enjoy!

author: Tahoe

title: Prusa i3 Rework X-carriage with additional holes for Wade's extruder

description.text:
This is a remix of the Prusa i3 Rework X-carriage by eMotion-Tech (thing #119616) to which I have added the standard 30mm apart holes for M3 screws and nut traps for a Wade's extruder found in many Prusa i3 variants. So now this X-carriage accepts not only all the extruders designed for the Prusa i3 Rework, but also most of the extruders designed for other Prusa i3 variants.
I have actually verified that the four LM8UU linear bearings provide more stability vs. the usual three bearings in the standard Prusa i3 X-carriage. Also the carriage itself is very well designed, looks good, prints easily and the teeth for the GT2 belt are perfectly defined. I also like the fact that there is a small separator between the LM8UU bearings, so they don't rub against each other.
I intend to use this new X-carriage with the P3Steel version 2.01 variant that I am assembling to achieve higher printing speeds.
OpenSCAD sources are included but need the X-CARRIAGE.stl file from eMotion-Tech to compile.

Printed in PLA with 40% infill. Requires 4 x LM8UU linear bearings and 8 x nylon ties. If using the Wade's extruder holes, also requires 2 x M3 nuts which should be heated with a soldering iron and then pushed into the nut traps, as shown.

comments.author: firepinto

comments.text: I used these bobbins in my 2013 Pulse Motor Build Off entry called the Planetary Tri-Vortex.  I used bifilar 21 AWG wire, I don't recommend that as I didn't have good enough power.  I would use a smaller gauge and not go with bifilar.  Take a section of the wire you plan to use and wrap one turn, measure that length.  Then take a bunch of small scraps of the same wire and pile them into the inner groove till no more will fit.  Count the sections of wire and multiply that by your wire length for one circuit.  Add extra length for build up of the wire in the grooves.  It's a crude way, but will get you in the ball park for winding your first circuit.  I would count the wire length of the first spool or what ever method you use to thread the bobbin.  Then measure the left over wire to subtract from your first spool's wire length, then your next spools will not waste as much wire.

Once printed, the 608ZZ bearing is a push fit in the spool holder.

description.text: Not a direct derivative, but similar to: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5551 I have found there are many times when I want to connect one piece of something to another. Having a generic trapezoidal key and slot system goes well for such applications. This set of things provides a simple trapezoid based key/slot system. The OpenScad file proves you the ability to specify the length of the span, and the thickness and width. You can print male/male, male/female, female/female. All the parameters are there for you to life the key/slot and use it in any of your designs. If you do, you'll have the ability to attach things together, with or without spans between them. Just one more thing in a set of somewhat useful things.

1) Look at whatever you're designing and figure out if there's anywhere a key/slot would be a useful addition.
2) Print an appropriate number of these spans, or incorporate the key/slot into your existing designs
3) Slide things together appropriately
4) Rejoice! As usual, it's press to fit. These will fit together and stay together nicely, as long as there's no real stress on them. If you want to make something permanent, you can always put a dab of glue/epoxy in the key/slot before you slide them together.

author: Gereau123

description.text:
For my students' end of the semester project, I challenged them to design a desktop organizer. The program they used was Autodesk Inventor.  
My goal for all of the projects that I assign is for my students to design a product that has some sort of use. I try to avoid small nic-nacs if at all possible.   
It was very rewarding to see my students get excited about creating this project. They were all very serious about getting all of there measurements exactly right, while also accounting for 3D printer tolerances. I was very happy with the overall results.  
The complete project guidelines can be found here: DesktopOrganizerProject.pdf

A quick word of caution:  
These projects averaged about 15 hours a piece, so about 150 hours total for all 10 students. So scaling this project down would probably be better.   
I posted a few of the source files so you can get an idea of how my studens went about their design process.

author: Makerconvent

description.text:
This is a basic guitar pick with a cutout design of two crosses inside of
each other. The 045 .stl file has these dimensions: 1.10 " wide,
1.29" long, and .045" thick. The 059 .stl file is the same size but
is thicker at .059".

I used Wings 3D to design the pick. The two thicknesses will
produce different sounds on your guitar. The thinner pick will
work well on an acoustic guitar, while the thicker pick will work
well on an electric guitar. This was designed in Wings3D using inches. You may need
to re-scale the .stl file by a factor of 25.4 if your program
uses mm.

author: Gereau123

description.text:
I love the show Supernatural and there wasn't a lot of Supernatural stuff on here so I made this.
The pentagram, or pentangle, wards off demons and evil spirits when one point is turned up.

I measured the diameter of a circle and placed a hole in the center to make the ring.
Creating the star was the most difficult part; I was trying to freehand draw it which didn't work, until my teacher suggested I take two pentagons and place them inside each other, then take the line tool and draw the star (this way it wasn't just a simple line, but the lines of the stars had depth).
Similar to my gear project, I had an extrusion problem the first time; the lines of the star extruded fine, but it took the area between two points of the stars and nothing I did could fix this.
Re creating it was easy. My only real issue with it is that the star's point weren't connected to the ring enough and the star doesn't stay connected to the ring.
Oh well.
I'll glue it.

author: Meep2

description.text:
I have always been a fan of the clouds floating along in Super Mario Bros so I thought I'd take a stab at creating a 3D 8-bit voxel version at 3Dtin.com. This is an exclusively 2.5D version (i.e. 4-axis millable extruded profile, more like a coin or a keychain). I added a Pendant version that includes a hook at the top for dangling this bling from your gold chain. 
Special shout out to Cory Arcangel, who I got to know while interning at Harvestworks a little before he launched his Mario Cloud cartridges!

comments.text: Surely not John Deere's Harvestworks?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Yep, the sprites for the clouds are the same as the bushes -- this is easiest to tell with the 3-cloud mario clouds.... Good eye!
comments.author: mifga

comments.text: Bonus! It's also the bush!
comments.author: Austin
